<target_code>
Here is the code of str_conn_error_:
```c
static const char *
str_conn_error_ (ssize_t mhd_err_code)
{
  switch (mhd_err_code)
  {
  case MHD_ERR_AGAIN_:
    return _ ("The operation would block, retry later");
  case MHD_ERR_CONNRESET_:
    return _ ("The connection was forcibly closed by remote peer");
  case MHD_ERR_NOTCONN_:
    return _ ("The socket is not connected");
  case MHD_ERR_NOMEM_:
    return _ ("Not enough system resources to serve the request");
  case MHD_ERR_BADF_:
    return _ ("Bad FD value");
  case MHD_ERR_INVAL_:
    return _ ("Argument value is invalid");
  case MHD_ERR_OPNOTSUPP_:
    return _ ("Argument value is not supported");
  case MHD_ERR_PIPE_:
    return _ ("The socket is no longer available for sending");
  case MHD_ERR_TLS_:
    return _ ("TLS encryption or decryption error");
  default:
    break;   /* Mute compiler warning */
  }
  if (0 <= mhd_err_code)
    return _ ("Not an error code");

  mhd_assert (0); /* Should never be reachable */
  return _ ("Wrong error code value");
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: return _ ("The operation would block, retry later");

if (0 <= mhd_err_code)
    return _ ("Not an error code");
return _ ("Not enough system resources to serve the request");
return _ ("The socket is no longer available for sending");
return _ ("The connection was forcibly closed by remote peer");
explanation: The only constructs that can produce indirect recursion are function or macro invocations that may ultimately call str_conn_error_ again. All return lines that invoke the identifier '_' and the call to mhd_assert are therefore flagged for investigation to determine whether these calls can (directly or indirectly) call str_conn_error_. Other fragments (switch statement, case labels, the if condition, numeric constants, and the function signature/return type) are non-invoking syntactic elements and cannot by themselves cause recursion, so they do not need further investigation for Rule 17.2.
